title: Research
text: My research spans ecology, evolution, and ecophysiology. I study the role that time and uncertainity play in shaping plant responses to the environment. In particular, I focus on plant phenology, the timing of annually reoccuring life-history events like growth, maturation, reproduction, and dispersal. Although I have specific expertise in alpine, arctic tundra, and agricultural systems, I view plant phenology as a unifying concept in ecology and evolution which integrates processes across biological scales. Plant phenology is an inherently individual and physiological process that can directly impact fitness, demography, and population persistence. Variation in phenological plasticity among species generates novel temporal community assemblies under variable environmental conditions. Taken together, these processes may scale to impact land surface phenology with critical implications for water, energy, agriculture, and ecosystem health.

title: About
text:
I am a PhD student & incoming Department of Energy Computational Science Graduate Fellow at the University of Colorado Boulder developing advanced statistical and simulation-based methods to improve our understanding of biological systems under uncertainty. My work focuses on plant phenology—the temporal dynamics of key plant life cycle events—in response to variable and often unreliable exogenous information. By integrating Bayesian generative modeling, machine learning, and high-performance computing, I aim to build theoretically-grounded, data-driven models that inform resource management and decision-making in dynamic systems, including agricultural and mountain landscapes. I work across R, Python, Stan, and Julia, with expertise in applied computational statistics, geospatial analysis, and remote sensing.
I am passionate about building generalizable computational tools that bridge scientific discovery and real-world application.
Outside of research, I enjoy rock climbing, running, cycling, fly-fishing, reading, film photography, and most of all, spending time with my wife.
